content.text:
# List of piers in the United Kingdom

at dusk]]
This is a list of extant and former coastal piers in the United Kingdom and Isle of Man and piers on the river Thames.
Coastal piers
England

|
|
|
| Major redevelopments in 2017, involving construction of a new amusement building. There are currently no plans to re-open the seaward end.
|
|-
| Folkestone Harbour Arm
| Folkestone
|Kent
|
|
|
! | (lighthouse)
| First used from 1904 as a port pier for ferries to Boulogne, France. Re-opened in 2016. Used as a pleasure pier, and for fishing.
|
|-
| Gravesend Town
| Gravesend
|Kent
|
|
|
! |
| On the Thames, and not a seaside pier recognised by most authorities.

| Pier of the Year following extensive restoration.

|

|

! |

! |
| The longest pleasure pier in the world, extending  into the Thames Estuary.

|-

|Hampshire
|
|
|
|

|Originally built to a length of  in 1871. The pier was extended and re-opened in August 1898.

|-
| Grand Pier
| Weston-super-Mare

| 2011
|
|
|
|-
| Birnbeck Pier

|Somerset
|
|
|
! |

|-

|Dorset

|
|
|
| Not recognised a seaside pier by most authorities. Built as a working pier rather than a pleasure pier.
|
|-

|1860
|
|
|
|Not recognised a seaside pier by most authorities. Category C listed structure. Closed to marine traffic since October 2018.
|
|-

| Kilcreggan
|
|
|
|
| Not recognised a seaside pier by most authorities. Passenger-only ferry to Gourock.
|
|-

| Rothesay
|
|
|
|
| Not recognised as a seaside pier by most authorities. Serves as a ferry terminal and small marina rather than a pleasure pier.

|-

| Fort William
|
|
|
|
| Not recognised as a seaside pier by most authorities.

{| class="wikitable sortable toptextcells"

|-
| Royal Suspension Chain Pier
| Brighton
|
|
|
|
| Destroyed during a storm on 4 December 1896.
|
|-
| West Pier
| Brighton
|
|
|
!  |
| Closed in 1975 and subsequently fell into disrepair. Now classified as a lost pier.
|
|-
|Coatham Pier
|Coatham, Redcar
|1873
|
|
|
|Demolished 1899.
|
|-
| Victoria Pier
| Colwyn Bay
|
|
|
!  |
| Closed since 2008. Partial collapse in 2017, leading to the demolition of the seaward end.
|
|-
|Victoria Pier
|Cowes
|1903
|
|
|
|Dismantled 1965.
|
|-
|Leith Trinity Chain
|Edinburgh
|14 August 1821
|
|
|
|Effectively closed in the 1850s and described as "deserted and ruinous" then destroyed by a storm on 18 October 1898.
|
|-
|Portobello Pier
|Edinburgh
|1871
|
|
|
|Designed by Sir Thomas Bouch, engineer who also designed the infamous Tay Bridge. Demolished in 1917 after repairs to storm damage bankrupted the owner.
|
|-
| Fleetwood Pier
| Fleetwood
|
|
|
|
| Destroyed by fire in 2008, hence a lost pier.
|
|-
|Leigh-on-Solent Pier
|Lee-on-the-Solent
|1888
|
|
|
|Demolished in 1958.
|
|-
| Lytham Pier
| Lytham
|
|
|
|
| Closed to the public before World War II following a period of decline. Demolished in 1960 despite protests from thousands of local residents.
|
|-
|Margate Jetty
|Margate
|1824
|
|
|
|Destroyed during 1978 North Sea storm surge on 11–12 January 1978.
|
|-
| Central Pier
| Morecambe
|
|
|
|
| Demolished 1992.
|
|-
| West End Pier
| Morecambe
|
|
|
|
| Demolished 1978.
|
|-
| New Brighton Pier
| New Brighton
|
|
|
|
| Demolished 1978.
|
|-
|Plymouth Pier
|Plymouth Hoe
|1883
|
|
|
|Wrecked by enemy bombing in 1941. Demolished in 1952.
|
|-
| Aberavon Pier
| Port Talbot
|
|
|
|
| Owned by British Transport Commission after being lost in 1962. Now a breakwater.
|
|-
| Redcar Pier
| Redcar
|
|
|
|
| Closed and demolished in 1980.
|
|-
| Rhos-on-Sea Pier
| Rhos-on-Sea, North Wales
|
|
|
|
| Lost in 1954.
|
|-
| Rhyl Pier
| Rhyl
|
|
|
|
| Demolished in 1973.
|
|-
|Victoria Pier
|Ryde
|1854
|
|
|
|Washed away in 1859. Replacement of 1864 storm damaged and demolished in 1924.
|
|-
| Scarborough North Pier
| Scarborough
|
|
|
|
|| Lost in 1905.
|
|-
| Seaview Chain Pier
| Seaview, Isle of Wight
|
|
|
|
| Demolished in 1952 after storm damage.
|
|-
| Shanklin Pier
| Shanklin
|
|
|
|
| Demolished in February 1993.
|
|-
|Southbourne Pier
|Southbourne
|1888
|
|
|
|Demolished in 1907.
|
|-
| St Leonards Pier
| St Leonards-on-Sea
|
|
|
|
| Damaged by bombing, gales and fire during WW2. Demolished 1951–55.
|
|-
| Ventnor Royal Victoria Pier
| Ventnor
|
|
|
|
| Four piers built on same site. Last one demolished in 1993.
|
|-
| Royal Victoria Pier
| Tenby
|
|
|
|
| Constructed as  structure and later extended. Lost in 1953.
|
|-
| Weymouth Pier Bandstand
| Weymouth
|
|
|
|
| Majority of pier demolished in 1986; only the entrance building remains on  of the pier. Thus not a seaside pier any longer.
|
|-
| Withernsea Pier
| Withernsea
|
|
|
|
| Partial destruction by storm in 1882 and ship collisions in 1890 and 1893. Last remaining section removed in 1903.
|
